verses.text: Now these are the generations of Esau, that is Edom.
verses.comment: This introduction signals the beginning of another genealogy, connecting Esau with the nation of Edom. It shows the enduring importance of family lineage in salvation history.

verses.text: Esau took his wives from the daughters of Canaan: Adah, the daughter of Elon the Hittite, Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah, the granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite;
verses.comment: The mention of Esau's Canaanite wives marks a contrast with Jacob, who followed the family's tradition. Such choices have implications for later divisions between nations.

verses.text: and Basemath, Ishmael’s daughter, the sister of Nebaioth.
verses.comment: Esau’s marriage into Ishmael’s line shows another divergence from the chosen family, but God sovereignly incorporates even these lines into His wider purpose.

verses.text: Adah bore Esau Eliphaz; Basemath bore Reuel;
verses.comment: The naming of sons preserves ancestral memory and underscores the fulfillment of God’s promise to multiply Abraham’s descendants.

verses.text: and Oholibamah bore Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These are the sons of Esau who were born to him in the land of Canaan.
verses.comment: The detail of their birth in Canaan highlights Esau's connection to, yet ultimate separation from, the Promised Land.

verses.text: Then Esau took his wives, his sons, his daughters, and all the members of his household, as well as his livestock, all his animals, and all he had gained in the land of Canaan, and he went to a land away from his brother Jacob.
verses.comment: Esau’s move prefigures later divisions among God’s people. It echoes the distinction between the physical and spiritual seeds in salvation history.

verses.text: For their possessions were too great for them to dwell together; the land where they sojourned could not support them because of their livestock.
verses.comment: Like Abraham and Lot before, the separation here is practical, but also has spiritual significance, as God’s plan unfolds through chosen lines.

verses.text: So Esau settled in the hill country of Seir. Esau is Edom.
verses.comment: The repeated identification of Esau as Edom connects him with a future nation often at odds with Israel.

verses.text: These are the generations of Esau the father of Edom, in the hill country of Seir.
verses.comment: The genealogy continues, linking the origins of Edom with Esau for emphasis and posterity.

verses.text: These are the names of Esau’s sons: Eliphaz, the son of Adah the wife of Esau; Reuel, the son of Basemath, the wife of Esau.
verses.comment: The genealogy is reiterated for clarity, a typical trait in ancient records.

verses.text: The sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.
verses.comment: Eliphaz’s descendants are later referenced among Edom’s tribal leaders.

verses.text: Timna was a concubine of Eliphaz, Esau’s son; she bore Amalek to Eliphaz. These are the sons of Adah, the wife of Esau.
verses.comment: Amalek would become a fierce enemy of Israel. The inclusion of Timna highlights the importance of recognizing all branches that stem from the patriarch.

verses.text: These are the sons of Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the sons of Basemath, Esau’s wife.
verses.comment: The record of sons establishes tribal identities within Edom.

verses.text: These were the sons of Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah, the granddaughter of Zibeon, Esau’s wife: she bore to Esau Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
verses.comment: Oholibamah’s sons compose another set of Edom’s tribal lineages.

verses.text: These are the chiefs of the sons of Esau. The sons of Eliphaz, the firstborn of Esau: chief Teman, chief Omar, chief Zepho, chief Kenaz,
verses.comment: "Chief" (Heb. 'alluph') designates a ruler or clan leader. These are foundations for later Edomite tribal organization.

verses.text: chief Korah, chief Gatam, chief Amalek. These are the chiefs of Eliphaz in the land of Edom. These are the sons of Adah.
verses.comment: The organization into clans points to development of social structures among Edom, paralleling later Israelite tribal organization.

verses.text: These are the sons of Reuel, Esau’s son: chief Nahath, chief Zerah, chief Shammah, chief Mizzah. These are the chiefs of Reuel in the land of Edom. These are the sons of Basemath, Esau’s wife.
verses.comment: Every lineage receives clan status; this shows how faithfully the descendants preserved the memory of their founding fathers.

verses.text: These are the sons of Oholibamah, Esau’s wife: chief Jeush, chief Jalam, chief Korah. These are the chiefs born of Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah, Esau’s wife.
verses.comment: Oholibamah’s sons form clans and complete the significant branches of Edom’s leadership.

verses.text: These are the sons of Esau, and these are their chiefs. He is Edom.
verses.comment: The formal repetition emphasizes Esau’s fatherhood of an entire nation.

verses.text: These are the sons of Seir the Horite, the former inhabitants of the land: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
verses.comment: The Horites were Edom’s predecessors in Seir. Their inclusion shows God’s providence in arranging who would inhabit the land.

verses.text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These are the chiefs of the Horites, the sons of Seir, in the land of Edom.
verses.comment: The Horite chiefs are named to record their displacement and integration into Edom.

verses.text: The sons of Lotan were Hori and Hemam. Lotan’s sister was Timna.
verses.comment: Timna’s role connects the Horites with the Amalekites, showing merging lines of non-Israelite peoples.

verses.text: These are the sons of Shobal: Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
verses.comment: The descendants of Shobal are listed with alternate spellings in some manuscripts; this translation preserves the most frequently found forms.

verses.text: These are the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah. He is the Anah who found the hot springs in the wilderness as he fed the donkeys of his father Zibeon.
verses.comment: The reference to hot springs (or 'mules' in some translations) is disputed in the Hebrew; here 'hot springs' is consistent with most modern scholarship.

verses.text: These are the children of Anah: Dishon and Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah.
verses.comment: This clause links Oholibamah, Esau’s wife, to Seir’s genealogy.

verses.text: These are the sons of Dishon: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
verses.comment: Preserves the Horite tribal lines, essential for understanding later Edomite society.

verses.text: These are the sons of Ezer: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.
verses.comment: Ezer’s descendants continue the record of Horite clans.

verses.text: These are the sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.
verses.comment: The name Uz is significant as later biblical traditions associate with regions east of Israel, e.g., the homeland of Job (Job 1:1).

verses.text: These are the chiefs of the Horites: chief Lotan, chief Shobal, chief Zibeon, chief Anah,
verses.comment: Lists the leading Horite clans, emphasizing social order and continuity by tradition.

verses.text: chief Dishon, chief Ezer, chief Dishan. These are the chiefs of the Horites, according to their clans, in the land of Seir.
verses.comment: Completion of Horite chieftain lists; the underlying text stresses indigenous governance prior to full Edomite dominance.

verses.text: These are the kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the children of Israel:
verses.comment: Edom’s early monarchy predates Israel’s. This foreshadows Israel’s future call for a king and God’s unique governance.

verses.text: Bela the son of Beor reigned in Edom; and the name of his city was Dinhabah.
verses.comment: Genealogical records such as this ground Israel’s neighbors in as much history as Israel herself.

verses.text: Bela died, and Jobab the son of Zerah of Bozrah reigned in his place.
verses.comment: Bozrah is a significant Edomite city, later recurring in biblical prophecy (Isaiah 34:6).

verses.text: Jobab died, and Husham of the land of the Temanites reigned in his place.
verses.comment: The Temanites are frequently mentioned in wisdom literature (see Job 2:11).

verses.text: Husham died, and Hadad the son of Bedad, who defeated Midian in the field of Moab, reigned in his place; and the name of his city was Avith.
verses.comment: The defeat of Midian points to the turbulent relations between Edom and nearby nations.

verses.text: Hadad died, and Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his place.
verses.comment: The sequence of Edomite monarchs is continued, showing succession rivaling that of Israel’s later kings.

verses.text: Samlah died, and Shaul of Rehoboth by the River reigned in his place.
verses.comment: ‘Rehoboth by the River’ refers likely to a northern territory; these details anchor the account geographically.

verses.text: Shaul died, and Baal-hanan the son of Achbor reigned in his place.
verses.comment: Such detailed royal lists are rare in other genealogies, highlighting Edom’s significance to biblical writers.

verses.text: Baal-hanan the son of Achbor died, and Hadar reigned in his place; the name of his city was Pau. His wife’s name was Mehetabel, daughter of Matred, daughter of Mezahab.
verses.comment: The final Edomite king listed marries into another distinguished family, a sign of political alliances.

verses.text: These are the names of the chiefs of Esau, according to their clans, places, and names: chief Timna, chief Alvah, chief Jetheth,
verses.comment: ‘Chiefs’ here again refers to clan or tribal leaders, showing the decentralized rule in Edom.

verses.text: chief Oholibamah, chief Elah, chief Pinon,
verses.comment: The repetition of names previously given demonstrates the careful preservation and honor for clan origins.

verses.text: chief Kenaz, chief Teman, chief Mibzar,
verses.comment: The listing of chiefs by region highlights the distributed leadership structure in Edom.

verses.text: chief Magdiel, chief Iram. These are the chiefs of Edom, according to their dwellings in the land they possessed. This is Esau, the father of Edom.
verses.comment: Closing the genealogy by again linking the Edomites to Esau. The careful organization into families and clans points to an ordered tradition passed down—much as later traditions would emphasize the significance of apostolic succession and unity around a founding figure.
